div.ab: to rest on a very clean & smooth table, & since it is desiccative, I knew it would dry out lor, what I let it do in order to reduce it to powder, & molding it with sand, once broken up with my fingers & the sharp edge of a knife. I oiled my medal because oil cleans it without spoiling it. And And having dried it & cleaned it with a linen, & small bristle brushes of pork, I once again lightly oiled it with clear walnut oil, & gently swiped it with a cloth so that the medal would not be too oiled; having already considered that in this way the medal should come out easily, because the white lead, wet with glair, which would not damage the oil. This worked very well. I molded a medal very cleanly in high relief, without it having any lumps, which a lot of good sands such as felt, burnt bone, & iron dross failed to do on the first attempt. I re-cooked it & my mold became hard like marble. And then I knew that sands used to mold big relief must be very moist with some kind of water, which gives body & firmness, like egg white, gummed water, or one water boiled with elm root. And lightly oil your medal. It can take as many firings as you want because it is as hard as glass. But soft lead & sour tin must be cast at a very hot temperature.

Since that moment, I have realized that even though this sand is excellent & can be cast often & molds very neatly, it is fat and it makes bubbles. In this way, the soft lead does not suit the mold well. But I have tried to mix it with lean sand, such as pumice, metal scrapings, & similar things, in order to give it body, & to help it come off easily, because lean sand alone does not come off easily; and yet it takes metal well.
left-top Try to mix white lead or minium with other sands.
left-top Oil & smear with aspic oil, which will disappear when reheated, because the oil causes bubbling.

left-middle It is necessary to mold with egg white, and then mix it well. And once it is in the box mold, beat it well on the top with a pestle, or something else clean. This helps to make molding better and come out more easily.
left-middle It is best to fill the box mold in one go, because the mixture made of several sands, and the one from mines, that you use to fill the box mold, damages it.

div.head: Green varnish for medals of copper
div.ab: Having casted them very neatly, cover them with sel de verre that we use for sand, & moisten it, & in three or 4 days it will be green. Oil them after & keep them under the dung.
The Flemish reglue their earthen pots with gold color, that is to say minium, massicot, & varnish.
